For Black History Month, we're going to profile prominent African Americans who had a significant and historic impact on Kansas City Public Schools.

Anna H. Jones graduated from Oberlin College, a private Ohio school that was the first American institution of higher learning to regularly admit black students. She taught at historically
black Wilberforce University in Ohio before moving to Kansas City, Missouri, in 1892 to teach at Lincoln High School. She later
became the first black woman to serve as a school principal, assuming leadership of Douglass School in 1911. Jones was a
co-founder, with Josephine Silone Yates, of the Kansas City Colored Women’s League, led fundraising for the YWCA, and served as president of the Missouri Association of Colored Women’s Clubs from 1903-06. She retired from Lincoln High School in 1919.

(Thank you to the Black Archives of Mid-America in Kansas City and LINC for the image and information.)

Given that approximately a million or more people may attend this event, and the widespread support for the Chiefs within KCPS, we are going to cancel classes for that day.

Once again, congratulations to the Kansas City Chiefs and to all of their loyal fans. Please be safe and responsible as you celebrate.
